history.content:
Real answer: It's $260k including stocks. You can get this at any top tech company. Do some leetcode, get a referral to Lyft, and you can get this graduating in 3 years. RSOs (restricted stock options) are what make this possible. FB/Google/Amazon/Lyft/Uber/Stripe probably all have similar $200k+ jobs. I know a lot of people in HKN/UPE who were able to get this type of offer.

----

Not a direct answer to your question, as I'm not even able to comprehend how this is possible, but just some advice I guess since I've seen a lot of posts like this recently and can understand the stress that comes with trying to secure a solid job out of undergrad:

Don't stress. Don't compare yourself to others in such a way that causes you to feel like you're doing something wrong - whether that be in your skills, your grades, or your paycheck. There's always going to be someone out there that has a job that pays more than what yours does, that's just life. Unless you're Jeff Bezos, someone in the world has more money than you. I feel like, especially as Berkeley CS/EECS students, we compare ourselves to others and want to make sure that we make what we deserve when we get to the real world. And that's probably rightfully so; every day, we try to somehow make it through what is arguably the most difficult and demanding undergrad computer science program in the country. But if we're constantly focusing on what others are doing and always looking up at those that we may view as more "successful" than we are, we'll never really be content with ourselves. I think Scott Shenker put it best in his final lecture last semester (which also happened to be my last lecture at Berkeley, which was really cool) when he said the following, which I wrote down because it was that impactful on me: "If you think you aren't smart enough to succeed, you're wrong. If you think that being smart is enough to succeed, you're wrong. And if you think success should be your ultimate goal, you're wrong. Stop worrying you aren't smart enough or that your grades aren't good enough. Just focus on something that you care about, and everything else will follow."

TL;DR: Don't worry how this specific person was able to make this much out of college. That's really awesome for her, and we should all strive to do what's best for ourselves. But don't make a huge paycheck like that be your goal, because chances are you won't get that. Hell, I'm content making just over half of what she's getting. Just focus on you and what you want to do with the amazing education you're receiving as a CS/EECS student at UC Berkeley, and I have no doubt that one day you'll end up with a job where you love what you're doing and making more than enough for yourself :)

------

Original student answer here - I didn't mean for my answer to come off as preachy or condescending in any way, so if it did I really do apologize. I was just trying to relieve any concern or stress both the OP and anyone in a similar position of possibly comparing themselves to others would have...because I know what it's like to be thinking the same things like "how did this person secure this salary" or "how did this other person get a job at this company while I got rejected" and I know that it's not fun. And seeing as the last post of this nature @8730 didn't lead to any positive outlook on the subject, I thought I'd offer a different type of answer. I'm not sure how my words were interpreted as condescending, but seeing as at least one person thought they were, again I am sorry. All of what I said was in good faith and in no way was I trying to demean anyone but rather just give my opinion based on my experiences and the experiences of those that I know. And as another note, I'm not the same anon replying in the followups below, so don't think I'm trying to make anyone feel like their opinion on the matter is wrong in any sort of way...

Real answer: It's $260k including stocks. You can get this at any top tech company. Do some leetcode, get a referral to Lyft, and you can get this graduating in 3 years. RSOs (restricted stock options) are what make this possible. FB/Google/Amazon/Lyft/Uber/Stripe probably all have similar $200k+ jobs. I know a lot of people in HKN/UPE who were able to get this type of offer.

children.subject: Comparing yourself to others only causes more stress. A healthy dose may be good but people tend to go overboard.
Please, I don't want to argue/have this discussion. Let's stay on topic.
Also I hope you realize it’s $260k TOTAL INCLUDING STOCKS. Her base as the articles says is $135k which is average for software engineers in the Bay Area. Articles always tend to over estimate.
$260k total including stocks is still $260k right (assuming she doesn't leave early)? Of course $260k salary would be better but it's still $260k right.

Well yeah assuming she doesn't leave but the entire 260k isn't liquid money that you could spend. My point is that on paper it does seem a lot but this includes a lot of extra compensations that most tech companies already offer so I wouldn't say her earning this much is like by any means extraordinary. It definitely is great and I would also love a salary like that when I graduate but a lot of grads who work at top tech companies or promising startups like Lyft can earn this much. 

So I guess here is the answer to your question: Work at a top tech company, HFT, or promising startup.
So leetcode + good projects + internship = I will get in to one of those?
Sure you’ll get an interview. Just study hard and you’ll pass them.
Also for larger companies, stocks are given as RSUs, i.e. you can't cash them all out after the first year.

@student_answer

I respect your good intentions, but that does not answer my question. I think all of us would benefit if we knew how to make $260k as a new grad. Comparing ourselves to others is how we improve. This goes for both nations, as well as individuals.
She has graduated. She only dropped in on a class for fun because she used to go to school here, and she went to Cal Day.

history.content:
Hi Everyone,

Quick reminder about the rules of EECS 101 Piazza. While it is fine to disagree with one another, it is not acceptable to be disrespectful.  Please adhere to the rules of this forum.

- Audrey Sillers

children.subject: Thanks Farid, I'm honored to have your stamp of approval haha :)

Although it wasn't exactly what the original poster wanted for an answer(I think it's chill to ask how ppl get 260K, I definitely studied total comps and asked a ton of people so I can be educated when it came time to negotiate), I really appreciate the anon above who gave that answer about not comparing. You're awesome, and I really loved how you incorporated Scott's final lecture. I thought it would be webcasted so I didn't take notes during his speech, so it was really nice reading this and remembering what he said.

And if the anon is reading this, lots of people have read your response and it probably helped them out a lot. In fact, 3 people personally reached out to me and said they loved your message.

I personally didn't find your words condescending or preachy. I thought your words were beautiful :) keep spreading your positivity and thoughts!

The article calculates total compensation in a strange way.

Salary: $135,000 base, with $60,000 bonus and $65,000 in stocks ($260,000 total) 

I highly doubt she is receiving 65,000 worth of stock per year, this amount generally vests over 4 years. Also when including bonus in calculating compensation, we generally split over 2 years (since you wont be getting a sign-on bonus year 2. 

A more informative way to calculate total compensation is base + bonus/(2 years) + stock/(3 or 4 years). 

By this calculation her compensation would be 135k + 30k + ~20k = 185 which is close to a standard new grad offer at companies like facebook/google/uber/etc. This is very achievable, especially if you negotiate with competing offers.

history.content:
https://www.businessinsider.com/software-engineer-with-260k-salary-how-spend-my-money-2018-6

This new grad in the article is saying she has a $260,000 job, but hasn't even graduated yet. How is this possible? Even the FAANG companies I know max out at $200k.. Please share some of your secrets..
history.subject: $260k new grad, how is this possible?
